metadata.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The appellant company is incorporated in the United Kingdom under the English Companies Act and has its registered office in London.
The appellant owns a spinning and weaving mill at Pondicherry in French India where it manufactures yarn and cloth.

Messrs. Best and Co., Ltd., Madras, appointed agents of the assessee under agreement dated July 11, 1939, invested with full powers in connection with the business including purchasing stock, signing bills, settling claims.
Yarn and cotton manufactured in Pondicherry sold mostly in British India and partly outside British India.
In accounting years 1941 and 1942, all contracts for sales in British India entered into in British India, deliveries made and payments received in British India.
For sales outside British India, payments received in Madras through agents.

Total sales for assessment year 1942-43 (accounting year ended Dec 31, 1941): Rs. 69,69,145; British India: Rs. 57,07,431; outside: Rs. 12,61,714. Of foreign sales, received in British India: Rs. 9,62,434; outside: Rs. 2,99,280.

Total sales for assessment year 1943-44 (accounting year 1942): Rs. 93,48,822; British India: Rs. 67,98,356; outside: Rs. 25,50,472. Of foreign sales, received in British India: Rs. 75,230; outside: Rs. 24,75,242.

Income-tax Officer found assessee resident in British India under Section 4A(c)(b) as income arising in British India exceeded income arising without; assessed total world income under Section 4(1)(b)(i) and (ii).
Order of Income-tax Officer confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Order of Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on May 15, 1946.
Assessee applied to Tribunal under Section 66(1) for reference to High Court; Tribunal referred questions.
High Court answered questions against assessee.
Assessee obtained certificate from High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

In reply to notice under Sections 22(2) and 38 for 1942-43, agents submitted return under protest on June 1, 1943, claiming apportionment under Section 42(3), declaring company non-resident; total world income Rs. 10,23,907; British India income after apportionment Rs. 4,58,026.
Supreme Court remanded case to High Court on December 22, 1952, reframing questions.
High Court (Satyanarayana Rao and Balakrishna Ayyar, JJ.) delivered opinion on February 13, 1953, answering questions against assessee on Q1, for apportionment on Q2.
Supreme Court final hearing and judgment on December 8, 1953.
Entire profits for 1942-43 received in British India; major part for 1943-44 received in British India.

legal_issues.text: Whether in view of the finding that the entire profits were received in India and the company is liable to tax under Section 4(1)(a) of the Act, the provisions of Section 42(1) have any relevancy?

Can the income received in India be said to arise in India within the meaning of Section 4A(c)(b) of the Act? If not, should only those profits determined as attributable to the operations carried out in India be taken into account for applying the test laid down in Section 4A(c)(b)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Profits should be apportioned under Section 42(3) between operations in British India and outside; company not resident under Section 4A(c)(b) as British India income does not exceed outside income after apportionment.
Income from sales in British India where manufacturing outside should be apportioned; Section 42 applies over Section 4.
Entire profits do not arise in British India; manufacturing profits arise at place of manufacture (Pondicherry).

respondent_arguments.text: Entire profits on sales in British India arise there; Section 42(3) applies only to deemed income under 42(1), not actual arising; full world income taxable as resident under 4A(c)(b).
Income received in British India taxable under Section 4(1)(a); Section 42 not applicable to actual receipt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(1)(a); Pondicherry Railway Co. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Ahmedbhai case limited to Excess Profits Tax Act and Section 42; no general apportionment for Section 4A(c)(b); 'arise' different from 'accrue'.

court_reasoning.text: Section 42(1) applies to deemed accrual/arising from business connection; not to actual receipt under Section 4(1)(a). Apportionment under 42(3) not applicable where tax basis is receipt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 42 only for deemed income; actual receipt under 4(1)(a) attracts no fiction of 42.

court_reasoning.text: Income received in India does not wholly 'arise' in India under 4A(c)(b); apportionment required between operations inside/outside based on general principles, not limited to Section 42(3). Manufacturing profits arise at manufacture place.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Accrue' and 'arise' treated as synonymous; composite business requires apportionment of profits to operations.

court_reasoning.text: Ahmedbhai Umarbhai not confined to Excess Profits Tax/Section 42; establishes general principle for location of arising profits in composite business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits attributable to manufacturing arise at place of manufacture, sales at place of sale.

holdings.text: Provisions of Section 42(1) have no relevancy where liability under Section 4(1)(a) on actual receipt.
Income received in British India cannot be said to wholly arise in India under Section 4A(c)(b); allocate income between operations in/outside taxable territories.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai Co., Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Apportionment of profits in composite manufacturing-sale business; profits arise at places of operations, not just sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: Turner Morrison and Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Section 42 not applicable to actual receipt under Section 4(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Bros. Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Residence under Section 4A(c)(b); major income source roots company there.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Company v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Income received in British India by agent taxable there.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Related case on same assessee; purchase operations in British India as profit-producing.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burugu Nagayya and Rajanna v. Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
Hira Mills Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Cawnpore

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for taxation on receipt/arising; residency test; apportionment for business connection; reference procedure.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed. Question 1 answered in negative (Section 42(1) irrelevant for Section 4(1)(a) receipt). Question 2 answered that income received does not wholly arise in India under 4A(c)(b); requires allocation between operations inside/outside taxable territories.
outcome.relief_granted: Directions for apportionment of income for residency test under Section 4A(c)(b); reassessment implied on correct basis.

key_quotes.text: "Profits are not wholly made by the act of sale and do not necessarily accrue at the place of sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle from Ahmedbhai case adopted for apportionment.

key_quotes.text: "The words 'accrue' or 'arise' though not defined in the Act are certainly synonymous and are used in the sense of bringing in as a natural result."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects distinction between 'accrue' and 'arise'; supports general apportionment.

key_quotes.text: "When a company in any particular year derives the major portion of its income from a country, it is a legitimate conclusion that the company has rooted itself there for that year."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains rationale of Section 4A(c)(b) residency test (from Wallace Bros.).
